pt: {sc}vicious{/sc} {sc}villainous{/sc} {sc}iniquitous{/sc} {sc}nefarious{/sc} {sc}corrupt{/sc} {sc}degenerate{/sc} mean highly reprehensible or offensive in character, nature, or conduct. {sc}vicious{/sc} may directly oppose {it}virtuous{/it} in implying moral depravity, or may connote malignancy, cruelty, or destructive violence.
{sc}villainous{/sc} applies to any evil, depraved, or vile conduct or characteristic.
{sc}iniquitous{/sc} implies absence of all signs of justice or fairness.
{sc}nefarious{/sc} suggests flagrant breaching of time-honored laws and traditions of conduct.
{sc}corrupt{/sc} stresses a loss of moral integrity or probity causing betrayal of principle or sworn obligations.

pt.t: city hall was rife with {it}corrupt{/it} politicians

pt: {sc}degenerate{/sc} suggests having sunk to an especially vicious or enervated condition.

pt.t: a {it}degenerate{/it} regime propped up by foreign powers

quotes.t: Three-tenths of a mile uphill from our mailbox on the road, that bend is so {qword}nefarious{/qword} that neophytes often skidded into a snowbank or wound up fender-deep in mud there.

Moreover, those starry-eyed states inclined to perceive international relations in moral terms frequently underestimate the {qword}nefarious{/qword} machinations of their competitors on the world political stage.

… I always give the same response: Just because Frank posed for pictures with every leading capo, underboss and cement contractor of the day doesn't mean that he joined them in their {qword}nefarious{/qword} underworld activities. Oh, occasionally he rode along on a hit or two, but that was just one of those social obligations …

et: Latin {it}nefarius{/it}, from {it}nefas{/it} crime, from {it}ne-{/it} not + {it}fas{/it} right, divine law; perhaps akin to Greek {it}themis{/it} law, {it}tithenai{/it} to place {ma}{mat|do|}{/ma}
